misconceptions.name: Implements distance calculator instead of reading a single grade
misconceptions.description: The program reads four coordinate values for two points and computes a distance instead of reading a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and compute the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read exactly one numeric grade (0–100) from the user, typically into a single variable such as an int or double grade.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a grade
Multiple doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) are read instead of a single grade value
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have implemented a different assignment (distance between two points) rather than the grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the point inputs with a single prompt like "Enter grade: " and read one numeric value into a grade variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (prompts, variable names, and calculations) matches a distance formula problem, not a grade input task.

evidence.note: Reads four coordinate values and prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of reading a single grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for A and B grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether the numeric grade is in the 90–100 or 80–89 ranges, because it has no grade-related conditionals at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this problem without using any conditional ranges, just by computing and printing a numeric distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution needs conditional statements (if/else-if) that test whether the grade is between 90–100 or 80–89 and then assign letters A or B accordingly.
symptoms: No if or else-if statements related to grade ranges for A or B
Computation is purely arithmetic (distance formula) with no branching
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented the wrong problem, so they omitted all grade-range conditionals.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce if/else-if conditions that check if grade >= 90, else if grade >= 80, and so on, and map those ranges to 'A' and 'B'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditionals in the program at all and no grade variable; thus correct Boolean ranges for A and B cannot be present.

evidence.note: Performs only arithmetic operations; there are no if/else conditions for grade ranges such as 90–100 or 80–89.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for C and D grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program has no conditions to classify grades into the 70–79 (C) or 60–69 (D) ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I do not need to break values into C and D ranges; I just compute and display a numeric result.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution should include additional else-if branches that detect when the grade is between 70–79 for C and 60–69 for D.
symptoms: No grade variable or range checks for 70–79 or 60–69
No branching logic that could yield different outputs for C vs D
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the problem implemented is unrelated (distance computation), the student never created conditional checks for C and D ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After handling A and B, add else-if statements that check grade >= 70 for C and grade >= 60 for D.
related_concepts: Ordering conditions for mutually exclusive ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The absence of any conditional statements makes correct C and D range handling impossible.

evidence.note: Program structure has no grade variable or conditional branches where C and D ranges would be checked.

misconceptions.name: No default or else branch for F grades
misconceptions.description: The program does not include any logic to handle grades below 60 or a default else branch for all remaining grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: There is no need for a final else case because the program always computes the distance between two points.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use an else (or equivalent) clause to categorize all remaining grades as 'F' when they are below 60.
symptoms: Program never examines a grade value, so it cannot have a default F case
Output is always a numeric distance, never 'F' or any letter
misconceptions.root_cause: By solving the wrong problem, the student omitted the grade classification structure that would include a final F case.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After checking A, B, C, and D ranges, add an else branch that prints 'Letter grade: F' for any remaining grades.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no if/else chain at all, which means an F default branch is entirely missing.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Final output prints a numeric distance with no conditional structure or default branch that could handle F grades.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs distance instead of letter grade
misconceptions.description: The program prints a numeric distance description rather than a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) corresponding to the input grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The desired output is the distance between two points, labeled as such in the message.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For any numeric grade input, the program should output a message like 'Letter grade: B', mapping the grade range to the correct letter.
symptoms: Output message: "The distance of the two points is ..."
No output containing 'Letter grade:' or any letter-only grade
misconceptions.root_cause: The student misinterpreted or reused code from a distance-calculation problem instead of implementing the grade mapping specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the distance output with a print statement like "Letter grade: " followed by the computed letter based on the grade's range.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric values to categorical labels
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only output is clearly for a distance calculation and never mentions letter grades.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Final output line describes a distance and does not map a grade to a letter such as 'Letter grade: B'.

misconceptions.name: Completely wrong question answered
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two points instead of a Grade Calculator, which was required by the problem statement (Q3. Grade Calculator).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to have implemented a solution for a different problem (calculating distance between two points) or submitted the wrong file for Question 3.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and printing a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F) based on conditional logic.
symptoms: Code calculates distance using x1, y1, x2, y2 inputs.
Program output is 'The distance of the two points is [value]'.
Variables are named x1, y1, x2, y2, dx, dy, and distance, instead of 'grade' or similar.
Missing conditional logic (if/else if/else) entirely.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely submitted an answer intended for a different question or completely misunderstood the assignment, potentially confusing 'Q3. Grade Calculator' with a geometric problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement (Q3. Grade Calculator) and write a new program that reads a single numeric grade and uses if/else if/else statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
related_concepts: Reading and Processing specific input types
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves a vector/distance problem (reading four coordinates and calculating distance) and contains none of the elements required for the 'Grade Calculator' problem (reading a single grade, conditional grading logic). This is a definitive failure to address the prompt.

evidence.note: The entire program implements distance calculation, not grade calculation. The class name also indicates the wrong problem ('Q3DistanceBetweenPoints').

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (calculating distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment or misread the problem requirements entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.

Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of assigning letter grades
Class name is Q3DistanceBetweenPoints instead of a grade calculator
No conditional logic for grade ranges
Output is completely unrelated to the problem
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have copied code from a previous assignment, misunderstood the problem statement, or submitted the wrong file.

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is unambiguously solving a different problem. This is not a partial misunderstanding but a complete implementation of wrong requirements.

evidence.note: The entire program implements distance calculation between two points, not grade classification.
Prompts for coordinates instead of a numeric grade as specified in the problem.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Output is about distance, not letter grades. Completely wrong for this assignment.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The program computes the distance between two points instead of reading a single numeric grade and mapping it to a letter grade using conditional logic, so it does not address the specified problem at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that this question requires a distance-between-points calculator (reading x1, y1, x2, y2 and computing a distance) rather than a grade-to-letter conversion program.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user and use conditional statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinate pairs ("Enter x1 and y1", "Enter x2 and y2") instead of a single grade input.
The code reads four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one numeric grade.
There are no conditional statements checking grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.).
The only calculation is a distance formula using Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy).
The output describes a distance ("The distance of the two points is ...") rather than a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the assignment prompt or reuse of code for a different problem (distance between two points) instead of implementing the required grade calculator with conditionals.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and rewrite the program to: (1) prompt for and read a single numeric grade (0-100); (2) use an if-else chain or similar conditional structure to check which range the grade falls into; and (3) print the correct letter grade in the required format.
related_concepts: Designing program logic to match requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (inputs, calculation, and output message) matches a distance-between-points exercise and none of it relates to reading a grade or producing a letter grade, indicating a clear mismatch with the given task.

evidence.note: This code reads four coordinate values, computes a distance with Math.sqrt, and prints a distance message, with no handling of a numeric grade or letter grade mapping as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Solved the Wrong Problem / Misclassified Task
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate the distance between two 2D points, which is a completely different task than the 'Grade Calculator' required by Q3. The provided code does not read a single numeric grade, nor does it contain any logic for grade calculation.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or written code for a previous assignment or a different question (perhaps Q1 or Q2, or a practice problem related to geometry) and submitted it for Q3 without realizing the mismatch. Alternatively, they fundamentally misunderstood the requirement for Q3, substituting a distance calculation problem for the grade calculation problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single integer or double representing a grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code calculates distance between two points instead of calculating a letter grade.
Input prompts ask for x and y coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single 'grade'.
The class name suggests distance calculation (Q3DistanceBetweenPoints).
The logic uses Math.sqrt and geometric formulas, not comparison operators for grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major misidentification of the required problem for Q3, possibly due to copy-pasting from an unrelated solution or severe inattention to the assignment prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the requirements for Q3 carefully. Delete the distance calculation code and write the logic necessary to read a single grade and use `if/else if/else` statements to assign the letter grade according to the specified ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly calculates distance between points, using four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2), which is completely foreign to the Grade Calculator problem requiring one grade input.

evidence.note: The class name suggests solving a distance problem, not a grade problem.
Input is gathering four coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2), required for distance, instead of a single numeric grade.
The core logic calculates distance, confirming the code addresses the wrong problem entirely.
